titleStmt.title: Many remarkeable passages from both Houses of Parliament from the 12 of May till this present concerning the great affaires of the whole kingdome : with many more passages of great consequence concerning Sir Edward Deering and divers other Kentish-men : and concerning a charge to be drawne up against them for their speedy tryall : with the examination of Mistresse Sanders, living at Ratcliffe, sister to Oneale, before the House of Commons the 12 of May, 1642 : also another examination by the honorable House of Commons concerning Sir Nicholas Cole and the inhabitants of Newcastle, May 13, 1642 : together with an order of both Houses of Parliament concerning the continuance of the terme at Westminster : likewise His Majesties letter to the gentry of Yorkshire, May 16, 1642.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: Many remarkeable passages from both Houses of Parliament from the 12 of May till this present concerning the great affaires of the whole kingdome : with many more passages of great consequence concerning Sir Edward Deering and divers other Kentish-men : and concerning a charge to be drawne up against them for their speedy tryall : with the examination of Mistresse Sanders, living at Ratcliffe, sister to Oneale, before the House of Commons the 12 of May, 1642 : also another examination by the honorable House of Commons concerning Sir Nicholas Cole and the inhabitants of Newcastle, May 13, 1642 : together with an order of both Houses of Parliament concerning the continuance of the terme at Westminster : likewise His Majesties letter to the gentry of Yorkshire, May 16, 1642.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Sovereign (1625-1649 : Charles I)

notesStmt.note: A news summary, to which are added the text of the order of "both Houses of Parliament," actually of the House of Lords and the text of the King's letter.
Reproduction of original in Thomason Collection, British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Many Remarkeable PASSAGES from both Hou≈øes of PARLIAMENT.
From the 12. of May till this pre≈øent, Concerning the great affaires of the whole Kingdome.
With many more Pa≈ø≈øages of great Con≈øequence concerning Sir Edward Deering and divers other Kenti≈øh-men, and concerning a Charge to be drawne up again≈øt them for their ≈øpeedy Tryall.
WITH The Examination of Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe Sanders, living at Ratcliffe, Si≈øter to Oneale, before the Hou≈øe of Commons, the 12. of May, 1642.
Al≈øo another Examination by the Honourable Hou≈øe of Commons, Concerning Sir Nicholas Cole, and the Inhabitants of Newca≈øtle.
Together with an Order of both Hou≈øes of Parliament, Concerning the continuance of the Terme at We≈øtmin≈øter.
John Browne Cleric Parliament.
Likewi≈øe his Maje≈øties Letter to the Gentry of Yorke≈øhire, May, 16. 1642.
London, Printed for T. Ryder.. 1642.

div.head: Many Remarkable Pa≈ø≈øages from both Hou≈øes of Parliament, from the 12. of May, till this pre≈øent, concerning the great affayres of the whole Kingdome.
div.p:
UPon the 9. day of this pre≈øent moneth of May, there was a Committee of the Hou≈øe of Commons ≈øate concerning the differences betweene Sir Nicholas Cole (Major) and the Towne≈ømen of Newca≈øtle; where witne≈ø≈øes were examined in that cau≈øe, and an Order i≈ø≈øued to be ≈øent to Newca≈øtle
forthwith to Ma≈øon Ca≈øtle for the bringing up of more witne≈ø≈øes.

Vpon this pre≈øent day there was al≈øo then given up at the Court gate a Command from His Maje≈øty by Sir Nicholas Hand for the ≈øpeedy repaire of all his Maje≈øties Servants in Ordnary to YORKE, upon paine of his Maie≈øties di≈øplea≈øure, the Hou≈øe of Commons falling into con≈øultation of the malignant party of the Kingdome, and among o ‚Ä¢ hers, of Sir Edward Deering, and the re≈øidue that were in≈øtructers in the late ≈øcandalous Petitions delivered from Kent and having prepared a charge again≈øt them, at a de≈øi ‚Ä¢ ed conference it was then moved for their ≈øpeedy triall.

Vpon the 12. day of this in≈øtant Moneth, one Mrs. Sanders of Ratcliffe, Si≈øter to Oneale, was brought to the hou≈øe of Commons upon report made that they furni≈øhed Oneale with con ‚Ä¢ eniencies for his e≈øcape, who being examined thereupon before a Committee appoynted, and denying thereof, was
committed to Cu≈øtody, till convenient time for her examination.
Divers Committees of this hou≈øe of Commons, were appoynted to meet on Wedne≈øday la≈øt in the afternoone, for Sr. Cornelious Vermud ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s Bill, for the Fines of Recu≈øants and other delinquents.
But the Body of the hou≈øe met and ≈øate in a Committee, for the nomination of the time and place, for the Sinod to meet, which occa≈øioned much conferring,

The Lords a≈ø≈øembled in this pre≈øent Parliament, received a Complaint again≈øt one Captaine Jackso ‚Ä¢ , who had formerly had Command in the Ile of Providence, before the ri≈øing of the Spaniard, by a Souldier for aff ‚Ä¢ onts under him that Voyage, and concerning ≈øome pretended oppre≈ø≈øions and traines laid to take away h ‚Ä¢ s life (by the ≈øaid Captain) after ≈øome debate thereof it was referred to a Committee for Examination.

Upon the 13. day of this pre≈øent moneth, 1642. The Hou≈øe of Commons taking into con≈øideration His Maje≈øties date Me≈ø≈øage, and the danger the Committees of each Hou≈øe underwent re≈øiding at Yorke, then after ≈øome debate they Voted, that who≈øoever hee were that ≈øhould attach or impri≈øon either the ≈øaid Members, or any other of each Hou≈øe, imployed on their ≈øervice, ≈øhould be accounted as an enemy to the State and Common-Wealth, &c. Which being acquainted the Lords at a Conference, it were a≈ø≈øented too, and a joynt Order i≈ø≈øued for the printing of the ≈øaid Votes.
And likewi≈øe Order i≈ø≈øued to the Sheriffe of Yorke≈øhire, for the ≈øending up of tho≈øe Delinquents in their County‚ñ™ formerly ≈øent for, but not yet appeared.

WHereas the Lords in Parliament, have this day beene Informed, That the King is Re≈øolved to adjourn the next Terme from We≈øtmin≈øter to Yorke; Upon which, The Lords ≈øent a Committee to the Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England, to know of him, whether hee had received my command touching the ≈øame, who acquainted the ≈øaid Committee, That hee had received command from His Maje≈øty, to i≈ø≈øue Proclamations and Writs, to that purpo≈øe.
Whereupon, This Hou≈øe taking the ≈øaid matter into con≈øideration, hath Voted: That the Kings removall of the Terme to Yorke, from We≈øtmin≈øter, during ≈øitting of this Parliament, is Illegall.
And hath further ordered, That the ≈øaid Lord Keeper ≈øhall not i≈ø≈øue out any Writs, or Seale any Proclamation, for adjourning the ≈øaid next Terme from We≈øtmin≈øter to Yorke, as afore≈øaid.

div.head: His Maje≈øtes Letter to the Gentry of York≈øhire, May, the ≈øixteenth, 1642.
To our right tru≈øty and well beloved the Gentry of York, and others of this our County of York, whom it doth or may concern.
div.p: WE have with great contentment con≈øidered your mercifull and affectionate An≈øwer to our Propo≈øition concerning the un≈øufferable affront which we received at Hull, We have not bin deceived in that confidence we had in your affection, wherefore we de≈øire you to a≈ø≈øure the re≈øt of your Countrymen, who through negligence were omitted to be sum ‚Ä¢ oned: that We ≈øhall never abu≈øe your love by any power wherewith God ≈øhall enable us to the lea≈øt violation of the lea≈øt of your Liberties, or the diminution of tho≈øe Immunities which we have granted you this Parliament, though they be beyond the Acts of mo≈øt (if not all) Our Predece≈ø≈øours; being re≈øolved with a con≈øtant and firme Re≈øolution to have the Law of this Land duely ob≈øerved, and ≈øhall endeavor onely ≈øo 10 pre≈øerve Our ju≈øt Royall Rights, as may enable us to protect our Kingdome and people, according to the ancient H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ors of the Kings or England, and according to the tru≈øt which by the Law of God and this Land is put into the Crowne, being ≈øufficiently warned by the late affront at Hull, not to transferre the ≈øame o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of our power concerning which Affront we will take ≈øome time to Advi≈ø≈øe, which way we may u≈øefully imploy your Affections, in the mean time we ≈øhall take it well from all ≈øuch as ≈øhall per≈øonally attend us, ≈øo followed and provided, as they ≈øhall thinke fit for the better ≈øafety of our per≈øon, becau≈øe We know not what ≈øuddain violence, or affront may be offered unto us, having lately received ≈øuch an actuall te≈øtimony of rebellious intentions as Sir-John Hotham have expre≈ø≈øed at Hull: Being thus ≈øecured by your affections and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance we promi≈øe you our Protection again≈øt any contrary power what≈øoever, And that you ≈øhall not be mole≈øted for your humble and mode≈øt Petition, as of late have been threatned.

closer.dateline: Given at Our Court at Yorke, May the 16. 1642.
